div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,461] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, April 5, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth, and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST:

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Arden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Badam and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODEIDAB, ADEN. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Thursday, April 5, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.

R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.p: HEAD OFFICE: LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.

Alexandria, Port Said, Luxor, Assouan, and Khartoum.
TOURIST AND GENERAL PASSENGER AGENTS, BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

Residents in Egypt proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their passage, where they may be consulted, and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of baggage and clearance at port of arrival.
Circular notes issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe.
Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at principal Railway Stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamer belonging to the Company leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan, and Wady Halfa in connection with trains deluxe to Kharioum. Moderate Fares.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT; Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Milan, Loverne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi at 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8.30 a.m. in time fro Express to Switzerland, Paris, and London, leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer. (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
FAR EAST LINES
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste Line

(Departures from Port Said) To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Columbo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama and Kobe, about March 5 and April 3. To Suez, Aden, and Bombay accelerated service about March 8 and March 17. To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about March 17.
East African Line.
(Departures from Port Said) To Suez, Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa Bay, and Durban, about March 5 and April 2.
Special rates for Egyptian Government officials, members of the Army of Occupation and their families.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.

An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.

div.head: The Housing of Officials
div.p: The Government has decided to make an experiment of a decidedly bold character in housing its higher officials. An official commu- nication to the Press, after mentioning the inadequacy of the house accommodation now existing at Cairo, and the consequent embar¬rassments of officials with fixed incomes whose rents have been raised often to prohibitive figures, states that the Ministry of Finance has decided to proceed forthwith to the construc- tion of a few experimental houses at Ghezireh to be let to Government servants at rents representing an adequate return on the capital expended. The rents, from £150 to £200 per annum in the case of the houses and from £100 to £120 in the case of two sets of flits, will of course be beyond the means of any bat the better-paid officials. The. Government is aware that the experiment will not benefit the smaller ' officials, and expresses the hope that private enterprise will supply their needs, and makes special reference in this connection to the Abbassieh Oasis Co., which has bean granted a concession on very favourable terms for the creation of a suburb beyond Ahbassieh. Should all else fail the Government will be compelled to consider what steps can be taken to ensure a (equate housing accommodation for this class of its servants. The proposal has been criticised with great severity by the greater part of the - European and native Press, and we believe it s to be regarded with disfavour by a large num¬ber of educated Europeans and natives, among them many officials, who consider that the smaller officials and those occupying an in¬termediate position, whose embarrassments from the deficiency of suitable houses and from high rents are proportionately greater, should have been the first to benefit from any such scheme on the part of the State.

We are quite ready to admit that the higher an official’s pay the greater the jealousy with which he is regarded, and that this sentiment may have inspired some of the criticism which has been bestowed on the scheme. But we consider that the authorities have not examined the scheme from the point of view of the man who will not benefit by it. If an official, he will argue that the embarrass¬ments of men earning from £800 to £2000 a year are as nothing to those of the function¬aries earning half or less than half of those amounts. If his temper is at all unangelic he will probably go farther and speak of favour-itism, with gestures and epithets, inspired by his irritation. Now we do not share the opinion of our hypothetical official, but we do consider that before taking this step the Government might have taken the public into its confidence. It would then have realised that the scheme was not likely to prove popular with any but a very limited class of public servants. As it is the authorities seem tons to have spoiled a good scheme by beginning at the wrong end. We quite understand that the general rise of prices and the lack of ac¬commodation affect functionaries in all bran¬ches of the public service, and that the diffi-culty of aiding the large number of petty employes has not been overstated in the recent official community. But we feel that a section, at all events, of the small or inter-mediate employes—married men with large families and good records for choice—deserved first aid. An officer with a simple bullet wound can give op his place in the ambulance to a private who has had the misfortune to stop some fragments of a shell, without loss of dignity, and we cannot help feeling that some of the victims of iniquitous rents might similarly have waited their turn with¬out very grave inconvenience. Moreover, a scheme that only aids officials who can afford to pay rents of from £150 to £200 a year is bound to Be misinterpreted. The Govern-ment has already been accused of raising up caste distinctions between the various classes of offi¬cials, of unduly favouring the British employes, who are certainly expected to benefit the most from the scheme, and of neglecting the com- | plaints of the poorer functionaries. All these criticisms may be refuted. “Suave mari magno, etc.,” has never been the motto of the 1 present Administration. But it is-a fair ques¬tion whether it was worth incurring them.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Savoy Small Dances.
The small dances at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, have come to an end for the season.
Dog Poisoning.
Stray and ownerless dog found in Helouan at daybreak on the 9th inst. will be poisoned by the police.
Port Sudan.
The Government has opened a credit of L.E. 315,000 for the construction of the necessary offices for the Sudan Government officials at Port Sudan.
The Mosque-el-Rifai,

The Khedive has decided that the Khedi- vial Wakfs shall bear the expense of rebuild¬ing the Mosque-el-Rifai, where are the tombs of the Khedivial Family. LE. 60,000 is to be allocated for this purpose.
Comptoir Financier.

The Board of the Comptoir Financier et Commercial d’Egypte has decided to confide the “signature sociale,” which up to the present has been entreated solely to Mr. Alfred and Mr. Benvenuto Campos, also to Mr. Giuseppe Campos.
Cantata.

We see by a notice in our advertising on7 j name that a performance of Stainer’s sacred cantata “The Crucifixion” will, be given on Mannday Thursday (I2 h inst.) at All Saints’ Church. Cairo. The collection made at the doors will be devoted to the Organ Fund.
Hotel Imperial.

Mr. Helmut Sorgenfrei, who for the past three years has been manager of the Bristol Hotel with Mr. Chas. Bauer, has taken over the management of the new Imperial Hotel in Cairo. Under his auspices the hostelry should have a successful future. It is situated in the Sharia Soliman Pacha.
Egyptian Trust and Investment,

We understand that the b inks of the Egypt¬ian Trust and Investment, Limited, will not he 1 finally close 1 before the 30th June. In this manner all the operations effected daring the ' first year’s working #ill be comprised. It must be borne in mind that this company only com- menced operations at the very end of May. Credit Lyonnais.

M. Adrien Mazaret presided at the annual ' general meeting, at Lyons. The dividend was fixed at 50 fr. the same as last time, payable 20fr. immediately and 30 fr. on September 25 next, less tax: The retiring directors, MM Adrien Mazerat, Rene Brice, and James Ros- 1 selli were re-elected. MM. des Vallieres, Le Myre de Vilers Pierre Tresca. and Thedore Vautier were elected auditors for the current year.
Round the World Tour,

We have received a visit from Innocenti Arnaldo a young man who having started from Rome on February 28 1898, is engaged on a walking tour round the world Mr. Innocenti has already covered a considerable amount of the globe's surface, and among his varied and interesting experiences is in¬cluded a four-months’ stay in the Italian Legation during the Boxer rising in 1901. On leaving Alexandria he will proceed to Gibraltar, whence he will walk to Calais, and hopes to reach London in August next, when his journey will come to an end. During his eight years peregrinations over 80 000 English miles, Mr. Innocenti informs us, he has only consumed 25 pairs of boots.
L’Oeuvre des Jeunes Economes.

The committee of that excellent Alexandrian charity "L’Oeuvre des Jeunes Economes des Pauvrea” will give their annual entertainment at the New Khedivial Hotel on Sunday next, the 8th inst., for the benefit of the institution. The programme is an attractive one and will include the following: Le Luthier de Cremone, a comedy in one act by M F. Coppre. The parts will be taken as follows : Fillippo. M. St. Christaki; Taddeo Ferrari, M. D. Aghion ; Sandro, M A Hornbostel.; Giannina, Mme. A. Nicolas. Les Femmes qui Pleurent, comedy in one act. by M. M. Siraudiu and Thiboust, will also be given. The caste is : Chambly, M. St. Christaki; Albert de Rieux, M A. Nicolas ; Jean, M. A. Yanacopouto ; Dalphine Chambly, Mme. Berr; Clothilde de Rieux, Mme. J. Lapotaire. A concert will follow. I
Fictitious Pharaohs.

There was told in Paris last week a moving story of how the Louvre is kept supplied with the mummies of ancient Pharaohs. The embalm¬ed remains of primitive kings have done very well in their own tombs, but the process was never intended to stand the ordeal of light in a glass case in a modern museum. Hence the mummies gradually fall to pieces, and as the supply of genuine Pharaohs fails, it has to be supplemented Cargoes of nameless mummies are shipped to France and are kept in the vaults of the Louvre to be brought out surrep-titiously as wanted to replace that of some historical personage whose bones have frittered away under the action of a northern atmosphere. This kind of substitution is carried out in the early hours of the morning and a correspondent of a Paris journal was on Wednesday week pri- vileged to assist at it.
Spend your Holidays at Mena,
The management of Mena House Hotel has arranged special terms for residents of Cairo, Alexandria, and country from the 10th of April to the 10th of May. [ Advt.]

div.head: OUR SPECIAL CABLES.
div.p: KING AND KAISER.
PROBABLE EARLY MEETING.
(Gazette’s Special Service )
LONDON, Thursday.

The London Correspondent of the “Petit Parisien” to-day affirms that it is very possible a meeting between the King and the Kaiser will take place at an early date. The correspondent adds that though sport will probably be assigned as the reason for the meeting, nevertheless it is invested with a political character from the fact that both Sovereigns will be accompanied by their Ministere.

div.head: Illegal Arrest in Egypt
div.p: The Maid of Honour's Case

In the case of the German maid of honour, Fraulein Mileweka, who has instituted pro-ceedings against Duke Ernst Gunther of Schleswig Holstein and against the Chamber-lain of the Court, von Blumenthal, for alleged false accusations made by them in Cairo, whither they had tracewd her in order to effect her arrest, it appears that when Egyptian authorities, ever loth to proceed against the foreigner, declined to take extreme measures in a case which reseted upon mere allegations, they were startled from their reluctance by Herr von Bleumenthal's statement that Milhew-ska was the leader of an Anarchist band, and that her arrest was the desire of no loss a personage than the German Emperor himself.

div.head: The Khedive
div.p: H.H. the Khedive will come down to Alex-andria from Cairo on Saturday next to open the Flower Show at San Stefano.

div.head: Council of Ministers
div.p: The council of ministers met yeseterday afternoon at Abdeen Palace under the presi-dency of H.H. the Khedive.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Two cases of the plague, both fatal, are reported from Keneh.

div.head: Quarantine in Turkey
div.p: A telegram from Constantinople states that arrivals from Port Said are subject to a medical examination.

div.head: Rotations
div.p: Summer rotations will commence on or about the 15th May. The first rotation will probably allow for a days working of outlets and machines and 12 days' stoppage.
Rotations suitable for rice will be imposed on a number of canals and sections of canals.

div.head: The Gash
div.p: The Italian engineers who have been at Kassala conferring with the technical delegates of the Sudanese government with regard to the regulation of the waters of the Gash have left on the completion of their mission.

div.head: Esbekieh Theatre
div.p: On Monday we had quite a pretty per-formance of La Poupee in which Mme Lambertini did so well that we regretted the paucity of the audience. MM. Crepy and La Freydiere were also capital form and the chorus, if their singing left something to be desired, acted capitally from start to finish. Mme Lambertini as the doll was capital, and the final scene, when M. and Mme. Hilarius, the former in a condition worthy of his namr, break into the monastery to find their daughter, was admirably acted.

div.head: Steamer Movements
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria yester-day morning.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT.
div.p: LAST DAY OF STAY.
T. R. H. LEAVE FOR PORT SAID.

T.R.H. the Prince and Princess of Wales visited the bazaars, the Citadel, and several of the mosques yesterday morning, accompanied by Sir Charles Cost and Mr. Richmond, and made several purchases at Mr. Joseph Cohen’s establishment.
On Tuesday morning H R.H. the Princess of Wales visited the Khan Khalil accompanied by Major Watson and Manefield Pasha. ,

At 4 o’clock yesterday afternoon, the Prince and Princess of Wales and their suite had afternoon tea at the American Agency as the guests of the Hon. and Mrs. Iddings. Among those present were Rear-Admiral Sigsbee and | the officers of the Brooklyn, Mr. and Mrs. Grew, of the Agencv, Lord and Lady Cromer, the Sirdar and Lady Wingate, Geo., Ms. and Miss Bullock, Judge and Miss Batcheller, Judge and Mrs Van Horne, Mr. M. de C. Findlay, De Martino Pacha and Mme De Martino, Major Watson, Col. and Mrs. C x, Col and Mrs. Markham, Col. and Mrs. Matchett, , Mr. Rumbold, Miss Danford and Miss Gardiner.
THE PRINCE’S BENEFACTIONS.
His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales has given a donation of twenty pounds to All Saints’ Church Fund, one of £10 to the British Benevolent Fund, and a similar amount to the | Cairo S. P. C. A. j
DINNER AT THE PYRAMIDS.

After tea the Royal party proceeded by motor to the Pyramids, where a multitude of Bedouins gave him an enthusiastic reception. Their Royal Highnesses rode round the Pyra-mids on camelback, and after visiting the Sphinx, witnessed a Bedouin fantasia. {
Dinner was served at the Government House at the foot of the Great Pyramid. Later in the evening the Royal party returned to Abdeen.

This morning large crowds witnessed the departure of the Prince and Princess of Wales from the streets and from the fronts and verandahs of the hotels along the line of route to the station. The Khedive and Lord and Lady Cromer, the former accompanied by an escort, preceded their Royal Highnesses to the station, where a guard of honour, comp-osed of Egyptian troops and a detachment of the 2nd R. Inriskilling Fusiliers, under the command of Major Wilding, was drawn up. At about half-past eleven, the Prince and Princess of Wales drove down, escorted by Cavalry and I Mounted Police, and followed by carriages containing the members of their suite. g

By his Royal Highness’s request the sendoff was a quiet one. Among those present at the sta¬tion were the Khedive, Prince Mohamed Aly, the Sirdar and Lady Wingate, the Prime Minister. 1 Mr Machell and Mr. Corbett. The usual mili- tary honours were rendered and the farewells were most cordial, the Prince and Princess expressing themselves as having been delight-ed by their visit. a
THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.

A discussion is going on in the local Press on the subject of the address of Abdul Hamid Pacha Seydek. President of the Legis- lative Council, to the Prince of Wales. It is asked why the Government has not thought fit to communicate to the Press the official text of the speeches exchanged between the Prince of Wales and the President of the Council, and it is suggested that the re- marks made by the President on the subject of education have caused displeasure. 8
MAJOR-GENERAL STOPFORT

Major-General the H n. Sir F. W. Stopfort, K. C. M. G., C. B., Director of Military Train-ing, Headquarters of the Army, who has been appointed to command the London District vice Lieut. Gen. Oliphant, K. C. V. O., C. B., served as A. D. C to the Chief of the Staff of the expeditionary force in Egypt in 1881. He was present at the battle of Tel el Kebir, mentioned in despatches, and received the the medal with clasp, bronze star, and fifth class Medjidieh. Promoted to captain in May 1884 in July of the same year he was made A. D. C. to the brigadier-general in Egypt and in February 1885 A. D C. to major-general of the Suakin expeditionary force. Afterwards be acted as brig de-major to Brigade of Guards was mentioned in despatches for service daring , cavalry reconnaissance, received clasp for Suakin and brevet of major June 15, 1885.

div.head: Amateur Athletic Sports.
div.p: Championship Won By Greek Athlete.

It may safely be said that the most absorbing topic discussed at the annual meeting of the Alexandria Amateur Athletic Club yesterday on the A.S.C. grounds was- the weather. And many were the aspersions cast on the Clerk of the Weather, who had so ill-favoured the great sporting event of the year in our town. Certainly the climatic conditions were of the most unseasonable charc-ter- cold, raw, and windy, with ominous clouds which obscured the warming sun's rays at intervals and made everyone shiver. After the boisterous weather of the past two days it was feared that we might have rain, but though the rain kept off, providentially, the wind did not abate and it was a moot point whether half a gale or a khamseem was preferable. However, the choice was not given to the committee, who had to do the best they could with half a gale. The wind was conducive to fast times and the times of the different races compared very favourably with those of some years past, albeit the spectators would have preferred it other-wise. There was a large attendance of the public, though not quite as large as we have seen on previous occasions. Many, no doubt, especially the ladies, were deterred from coming by the unfavourable state of the weather, which was not conducive to a due display of now spring frocks,and though, as one spectator remarked, the grandstand was a 'galaxy of color', we have seen it look much brighter than it was yesterday. The ground bore a gray appearance, with flags and banner flying in every direction. Among those present we noticed some officers belonging to the American cruiser Brooklyn and the Austro-Hungarian Squadron.

Athletically, the meeting was a great success, the one blot being the poorness of the entry in the quarter-mile race. This must be a count-ed for by the fact that the race is of such a punishing character that men running subse-quently in the half-mile prefer to give it a wide berth. It was with regret that we noted the very poor reponse to the one event open to all comers- the obstacle race. The Clerk of the Course had put his whole back into the arrang-ing of obstacles. The result was most pleasing to the eye and should have afforded unlimited amusement to the spectators. Only four, however, turned out for the race instead of the fifteen or twenty we have generally seen. The tug-of-war, too, was confided entirely to the "Dublins". "A" team winning the final after a pull of about four minutes. The Alexandria police failed to put in an appearance for their match with the fire brigade, who were given a walk-over. In the open 100 and 220 the handicappers gave Aly Fahmy Ahmed a task just a little beyond his ability, fine runner though he is.

Reverting to the club events, we have with much regret to report an accident to J.R. Lees, last year's champion. He has been doing exceedingly well in practice this year and gave indications of possibly repeating his performance of last year. After getting a second from scratch in the 150 yards, he won the 100 from a 1-yard penalty, but in the winning of it, in fact, just after passing the post, he fell heavily and so injured his collar-bone that he was unable to take further part in the sports. But for this accident we might have seen a keen competition for the championship. E. A. Willmott, from short marks, was successful in the two sprint handicaps and came in a very good second in the 100 yards. He would have made a bid for Lord Cromer's Cup had he entered for more events. The champion of the day was E. Tsaloumas, an exceedingly good all-around athlete. He won all the jumps and the hurdle race and was second in putting the shot. His points numbered 28 and his nearest opponent was Willmott with 19. Tseloumas is a Greek who has youth on his side. He is going to Athens for the Olympic games and we wish him success, although he will come in contact with a different class of opponents in the jumps. He is a useful runner also, but for some reason or other did not enter for the sprints. The result of the sports might be called a Greek invasion, as besides the all-round success of Tseloumas we have to chronicle a magnificent "put" of 37 feet 7 1/2 inches in the shot by Veranakis. This is better than has been done for about twenty years, the nearest to it in that time being 36 feet 6 inches-also by a Greek, Valissarides. We must not omit the mention of Tseloumas' jump of 20 feet 4 inches, which beats by two inches the record for the course. In the half-mile there were ten runners. Peel, last year's winner seemed to crack up early against the wind and J.D. Carver off the 40 yard mark came in a few yards ahead of Blythman (scratch), who was confidently expected to win. Blythman in his turn was a good way in front of Wallace. The journey down to the hurdle almost in the teeth of the wind militated against fast time being done but 2 minutes 12 1/5 seconds was very fair. The Veterans' Race was the best seen for many years, and the large entry is encouraging to the continuance of the event on the programme. Gooding, from a long start, was too speedy for the rather heavily penalized Freeman, a dual winner of this race, and he romped in a fairly easy winner. Burrill, also penalised, was a good third. The Children's Race, a most popular event filled very well and afforded plenty of amusement. Lillian Cheva-ier, a 6 year old, got in a yard in front of Marion Percival, with Lionel Burrill, a chip of the veteran, a few inches behind. The handi-cappers, who have very thankless tasks to undertake, did their work uncommonly well, as the judges and referees can testify, the finishes in the sprint handicaps giving them something to think about.
At the end of the day, after being handed a handsome bouquet by the hon. secretary

Madame Girard presented the prizes with a few graceful words of congratulation to the winners. Mr. Haselden called for three cheers for the champion, which were very heartily given, his success being especially gratifying to a large number of his compatriots. Mr. Gould proposed three cheers for Mme Girard for her kindness in giving away the prizes, and on the call of M P. W. Carver, the clerk of the course and the hoc. secretary were similarly honoured. By the kindness of Col. Bird, D.S.O., and. the officers of the Dubline, the regimental and the fife and drum bands played selections during the afternoon. The prizes were, as usual, very handsome and well-chosen, reflecting credit on the prize committee. The following are the results of the different competitions
150 YARDS HANDICAP E. A. Willmott (3 yds.),1 ; J. R. Lees (scratch) 2 ; J. B Clarke (4yds.) 3. Won by inches; inches also between 2nd and 3rd, the rest well up. Time: 15 secs

100 YARDS (Open).—Abdel Gawad Abou Hussein 1 ; Hussanein Fahmy 2 ; AH Fehmy Ahmed (pen.- 4 yds.) 3. This resulted in a dead heat for first place. On running off. Abdel Gawad won by two yards. Time: 11 1/5 secs.
PUTTING THE SHOT HANDICAP —A. Varana¬-kis ( or) 1. —37- ft. 7 1/2 in. E. Tsaloumas (allowed 4 ft.) 2. -86 ft. 5 in.

100 YARDS RACE. J. R. Lees (penalized 1 yd.) I; E. A. Willmott. 2 ; J. B. Clarke, 8. Won by inches ; third a yard away, inohes in front of Blythman. It was in this race that Lees came down as a result of a successful effort on the team. Time : 11 secs.
HIGH JUMP HANDICAP —E Tsaloumas (al¬lowed l in.) 1. 5 ft. in. ; 8. R. P. Carver (allowed 1 in.) 2 5 ft.
200 YARDS (open) HANDICAP — Abdel Gawad Abou Hussein (2 » yds.) 1 ; Imman Wakid (2 yds) 2; Hassanei Fihmv (10 yd-.) 3 W n easily by four yards. Time : 24 '7.5 sec.
200 YARDS HANDICAP — E. A. Willmott (4 yd-.) 1 ; H C. Sedgwick (10 yds ) 2 ; A. C. Shepherd (14 yds.) 3. Won by a yard ; same between second and third. Time : 23 2/5 secs.
THREE LEGGED RACE Ptes. Collins end Wil¬liam, 1; Maguire and Butman, Sparrow and Evans, equal 2.
POLE JUMP.—E. Tsaloumas, 1; R B Mo Lean (pen. 3 in.) 2 .Tsaloumas cleared 8 ft 9 in., at which McLean failed, due to the fact that he was suffering from a sprained foot.
1/2 MILE HANDICAP.—A. C. Shepherd( 10 yds.).
1; H. C. Sedgwick (20 yds.), 2; E. G Henley (40 yds.) 3. There were only five starters in this event. Shepherd won by five yards from Sedgwick with Henley another four yards away. Time: 54 sec.
CHILDREN'S RACE. There were 36 starters for this race which was won by Lillian Che- valier, Marion Percival being second and Lionel Burrill third.
LONG JUMP HANDICAP. E. Tsaloumas ( cr.)
1. 20 ft. 4 in. C. E. Dianelli- (allowed 1 ft 8 in ) 2 This is the second jump of over 20 ft. which has ever been done at these sports and the above now stands as a record
BOYS’ RACE (EUROPEAN). -Thomas Bent 1; Felix Carver, 2 ; E win Cree, 3.

VETERANS’ RACE. 120 Yards Handicap — Gooding. 1; Freeman (pen. 4 yds.) 2 ; Bnrrill (pen 1 yd), 8. We cannot give the starts of these athletes as we would thereby give away their ages, but this winner didn’t have very far to run. Won easily by 2 yards; one yard between 2nd and 3.
NATIVE BOYS’ RACE —Abbas Hilmy Zewar.
1; Said Y ‘kan, 2; Abmad Shonkry, 3.
120 YARDS HURDLE RACE E. Tsalonmas (owes 49yd-.), 1; A. W. Malony (owes 9 yd:.),
2; S. R P. Carver (ow«e 9 ydf>) 8. Won easily in excellent style by five yards; third once up. Time: 18 1/5 sees.
TUG OF WAR. Fire Brigade v. City Police.
Fire Brigade a walk-over.
TUG OF WAR (open to Army and Navv).
“A” team Dubline 1 ; “B” team Dubline 2.

HALF Mile HANDICAP. -J. D. Carver (40 yds.), 1; Mr. Blythman (scratch), 2; J. S B, Wallace (4 " yd-.), 3. Carver was first round the hurdle and was never afterwards headed. He won by four yards from Blythman, who was half-a-dozen yards in front of Wallace.

div.head: A CONSTITUTION FOR EGYPT.
div.p: SHEM EL-BAKRI AND LORD
DUFFERIN.

The “open letter,’’ which Sheikh el Bakri has addressed to the Prince of Wales on the subject of a constitution for Egypt, is based in great part on the celebrated Report of Lord Dufferin. Bat the establishment in Egypt of a system of representative government as Lord Dufferin summed up in his 'Synopsis of Proposed Egyptian Institutions” will never be possible in Egypt as it is contrary to the fundamental ideas of the Oriental, for even the most modified form of Parliamentary system baa not, and is never likely to have, the slightest chance of taking root in a country like Egypt. None of the other reforms suggested by Lord Dufferin were so Utopian as this. In nearly all other matters be not only laid his finger at once on the ailing spot, but the remedies he suggested, if frequently incapable of immediate application, were al-ways sound in themselves and have in many instances been subsequently applied.

Lord Milner’s criticism of the proposals of Lord Dufferin, whereon Sheikh el Bakri bases in great measure his arguments, are much to the point The passage run as follows :— “He was right in not despairing of the ultimate independence of Egypt; he was right in effort. But on the other hand, he certainly glossed over the deep-rooted obstacles which his scheme of reform was bound to encounter, and above all the length of time which would be required to accomplish it. His rose-coloured picture of an Egypt ‘un¬-trammelled’ by external importunity, though aided by sympathetic advice and assistance,’ of the Egyptians governing themselves on civilized principles without an irritating.and exasperating display of authority on our part, though ‘under the uncompromising series of our friendship,’ was exactlv united" to hit the pre¬vailing taste, both in Egypt and Great Britain.

It flattered the self-importance and the shallow Liberalism of the Pachas, always ready to sym¬pathise with reforms, until they began to come home to them in the shape of harder work, diminished license, and fewer opportunities of self-enrichment. I was no less grateful to the British people in their honest desire to play the part of guide, philosopher, and friend to the people of Egypt, but to play it cheap. And it the same time it concealed from both parties he disagreeable side of the business : from the Egyptians, the long period of irksome control and training through which they would have to pass on their [gap] to a civilised independ-¬ence ; from the English, the corresponding period of close attention to the affairs of Egypt and the effort, anxiety, and risk which such attention involved.”

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H.H. Prince Muhamed Aly is leaving on Saturday next by the Austrian boat for Europe to spend the summer season. His Highness will leave Cairo that day by the 9:30 a.m. express, arriving at the Austrian Lloyd berth at 1.15 pm.

Prince Leopold of Battenberg has arrived from Port S rid at Marseilles on board the P. 4 0. S.S. Caledonia. We understand ■hit the Prince has considerably benefited in health by his sojourn Egypt this season.
Princess Louise (Duchess of Arryll) and the Duke-of Argyll have returned to Ken- sington Palace from Egypt.
The Dean of Norwich has also arrived home.

Among the passengers who left Alexandria yesterday afternoon by the North German Lloyd’s S.S. Schleswig were Count and Countess Ablefeldt-Bille, Freiherr von Bibia, Mr. Mrs. and Miss Bovill, General Baden-. Powell, Mr. Herri Debourg. Mr Kaul. Colonel Maberly, Mr. Erie Mosseri, Seifoullah Pacha Yousri and Princess Yousri. Count de Vibraye, Mrs. and Miss Waheman Long, etc.
Among these who are due at Port Said by the P.andO. S.S. Caledonia are Sir Squire Ban¬croft and Colonel Sir Francis Younghusband, K.C.I.E.

Miss C. H. Kerr, R. R. C., who has come from South Africa to take over the duties of Matron-in-Chief at the War Office, was ordered to Egypt in 1888 but the campaign proving a very short one it was over when she arrived, and most of her stay was spent in Alexandria. She served throughout the South African campaign.

Captain J. A. Byrne, 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, is leaving for Cyprus on the 9th inst., for duty in connection with a court martial to be assembled there. On the termina¬tion of the court martial proceedings he will proceed to Crete for duty with the detachments of his unit stationed there.
Maitre Athanassaki, who has ore of the best practices among the Greek barristers at the Cairo Mixed Bar. is leaving Egypt on Wednesday next and intends to settle down at Athens.
